item.title: Understanding Pearl's Front-Door Magic
item.description: Judea Pearl’s brilliant algorithmic framework for causal reasoning called do-calculus can intimidate even a seasoned statistician. I will try to present an intuitive justification of a couple of its common patterns – namely the back-door and, the seemingly magical, front-door adjustment formulas. Along the way I will derive the front-door formula (for a special case) without appealing to the rules of do-calculus. In a previous post I attempted to explain the distinction between Bayesian and causal (or interventional) conditioning by introducing the do notation.
